Renewable SiO2 as support for NiO catalyst for regioselective synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles from azide-alkyne cycloaddition in aqueous media Sasikumar Boggala a b Vijayanand Perupogu c Shirisha Varimalla a Kalpana Manda a b Venugopal Akula a b ⁎ a Catalysis and Fine Chemicals Department, CSIR - Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad-500 007, Telangana State, India Catalysis and Fine Chemicals Department CSIR - Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad-500 007 Telangana State India aCatalysis and Fine Chemicals Department, CSIR - Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad-500 007, Telangana State, India b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad, 201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India bAcademy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad, 201002, India c Energy and Environmental Engineering Division, CSIR - Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500 007, Telangana State, India Energy and Environmental Engineering Division CSIR - Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad Telangana State 500 007 India cEnergy and Environmental Engineering Division, CSIR - Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500 007, Telangana State, India ⁎ Corresponding author. SiO2 derived from rice husk (SiO2-RH) has been used as a support for NiO catalyst for azide-alkyne cycloaddition in aqueous media at 60 °C. The 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst was found to be an efficient and reusable catalyst for the regioselective synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles with broad substrate scope that included carbohydrate triazoles and one-pot synthesis of triazoles. The reaction mechanism followed through a nickel π-complex on the surface of the NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst. The catalyst was recycled up to four times that showed consistent activity and selectivity. The structure-activity correlation and mechanistic studies were established by BET-SA, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, SEM-EDX, XPS, XRD, 29Si SS MAS NMR and H2-pulse chemisorption studies and a plausible reaction mechanism has been proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Rice husk-SiO2 Nickel catalyst 1,4-Disubstituted 1,2,3-Triazole Regioselectivity 1 Introduction In the recent past, organic alkynes and azides were converted to triazoles by the Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition. The thermal cycloaddition requires high activation barriers with a limitation on the desired products due to a lack of selectivity at certain temperatures. The Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction was limited by several drawbacks, such as temperature, long reaction time, and very poor regioselectivity [1]. In a report by Sharpless et al. [2], copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) access to 1,4-disubstituted products with high yield and regioselectivity was reported. The synthesized carbazole, phenothiazine and other substituted triazoles have shown excellent activity in biological studies and as drugs. Recent studies have revealed a great interest in the synthesis of 1,4-substituted triazoles as these triazoles are key scaffolds in luminescent sensors and biologically active compounds for several applications [3–7]. Of the many, homogeneous transition metals (Ir, Ru, Pd, Zn, Ni) catalyzed click reactions are explored to access 1,4- or 1,5-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles [8–12]. However, some of these systems have few complications for the synthesis of triazoles, for example in the recovery and reuse of expensive metals and the use of co-catalysts such as additives, reducing agents and stabilizing ligands. Using solid catalysts such as AuAAC, AgAAC and CuAAC, the click reaction has been examined under heterogeneous conditions [13–16]. Kim et.al. reported a homogeneous Cp2Ni catalyst using xantphos as a ligand and a hard base for the synthesis of disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles [17] which gave reverse regioselectivity compared to the results presented in this investigation. Surya Prakash and Guravaiah reported a method for the synthesis of 1,4-triazoles with Raney Ni as a catalyst in an organic solvent (toluene) at 45 °C for 12 h [18]. Priti et.al. reported the formation of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole over Ru(II)/SBA-15 catalyst at 90 °C in 12 h [19]. Rej et.al. described a method for the synthesis of 1,2,3-triazole using a gold-based catalyst with 1 eq of TEA [20]. Earlier, Chen and co-workers established that 10mol% of zinc on charcoal exhibited the azide-alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) reaction at 50 °C within 15–20 h [21]. Nunesa et al. [22] described a method using a Cu(II) phen@SBA-15 catalyst at 70 °C for 6–14 h. Wang and Miao established a method with a modified silica-supported copper catalyst at 80 °C for 24 h for AAC reaction [23]. Nia et al. reported on the CRGO-Ima-CuI catalyst for the click reaction at 40 °C for 72 h [24]. Most of these reports show exploration of expensive catalyst systems under basic reaction conditions with limited substrate scope and most of the reports were on the synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles using aliphatic or benzyl azide and monocyclic alkynes. The 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole derivatives are very important compounds, for example carbazole (CBZ) showed metal ion sensing, antitubercular and antimycobacterial activities [25,26]. Phenothiazine (PTZ) [27] and phenoxazine (POZ) [28] derivatives were known for various biological activities such as psychotropic, antitumor, anti-helminthic and pharmacological properties [29]. The present study is also focused on the synthesis of carbohydrate-based triazoles using the solid 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst with glucopyranosyl and galactopyranosyl azides as the 1,4-disubstituted carbohydrate 1,2,3-triazole derivative compounds, which have a wide range of biological activities such as inhibitors, anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer and many pharmaceutical drugs [30–33]. The challenge still remains in developing a click reaction to generate the bio-molecule triazoles and one-pot synthesis of triazole from in-situ generated azides over the solid heterogeneous recyclable catalyst under eco-friendly conditions. Herein, we report a heterogeneous NiO catalyst to access 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles through azide-alkyne cycloaddition under the green protocol. For this purpose, the rice husk derived SiO2 was used as a support for NiO and the reaction was performed under base and ligand free conditions in aqueous media at moderate temperatures with shortest purification steps. The interaction between NiO and SiO2-RH led to enhanced catalytic activity for this transformation [34,35,53]. The SiO2-RH has a high specific surface area, good thermal stability and hence tremendous synthetic potential in green protocols [36–39]. The dispersed NiO particles on SiO2-RH demonstrated high yield and selectivity. The surface and bulk properties of these catalysts were rationalized by BET-SA (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller - surface area), powder XRD (X-ray diffraction), H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction), NH3-TPD (temperature programmed desorption), SEM-EDX (scanning electron microscopy energy dispersive X-ray), SS-MAS (solid state magic angle spinning), NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance), XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) and H2-pulse chemisorption studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and method Nickel(II)nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), fumed silica (F-SiO2), bases, alkynes, azides, phenacyl bromides, sodium azide (NaN3) and other required chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as such without purification. All the solvents used in this work were purified by standard procedures. All the chemicals used in this work were of analytical grade. Various alkynes and azides were prepared according to previous reports shown in [ESI]. 2.2 Preparation of rice husk derived silica The preparation of SiO2 from rice husk is denoted as SiO2-RH, as shown in Figure S3. First, the rice husk was washed with distilled water to remove the soil particles, followed by drying at 90 °C in a hot air oven. Furthermore, the acid leaching and pyrolysis processes have been carried out as follows: the dried rice husk was contacted with 0.1 M HCl in a glass beaker at 80 °C within the thermostat for 5 h. It was then filtered and washed repeatedly with hot distilled H2O to ensure that the filtrate was free from acid followed by drying the rice husk up to complete moisture free at 90 °C. The pyrolysis of this gel was performed under an air atmosphere (airflow ≈ 30 cm3 min−1) with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 up to 200 °C with a holding time of 2 h followed by further heating at the same heating ramp up to 400 °C and holding for 2 h subsequently at 600 °C for 2 h was maintained to achieve a high surface area SiO2-RH. The sample was allowed to cool down in the presence of airflow. The rice husk ash without acid leaching contained 81.6% of SiO2 and certain amounts of impurities present in it (Table S3). However, the impurity levels are drastically reduced after acid leaching and the silica content is found to be >95.7% [37]. The prepared rice husk silica (contained 95.7%) was used as a solid support for nickel without removing the impurities. 2.3 Preparation of rice husk derived silica-supported nickel oxide catalysts The nickel with varied loadings from 5 - 15wt% supported on SiO2-RH samples were prepared by a simple wet impregnation method and a 10wt%NiO supported on fumed SiO2 was prepared for comparative analysis. In a typical method, an aqueous solution containing Ni(NO3)2 6H2O was added to SiO2-RH at the required wt% of nickel and stirred continuously until completely dried. These samples were dried at 100 °C for 12 h in an oven and calcined at 450 °C for 5 h in static air. All the samples are denoted as x wt% NiO/SiO2-RH where x = 5.0, 7.5, 10.0, 15.0 unless otherwise mentioned. 2.4 General method (A) for Ni catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (NiAAC) The mixture of 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH (0.05 g), alkynes 1 (0.5 mmol), organic azides 2 (0.45 mmol) were added in a 10 mL round bottom flask and 4 mL H2O (solvent) at room temperature. The mixture was refluxed at 60 °C for 10 h in the open air. The catalyst was removed by simple centrifugation after the reaction and washed with H2O, dried in an oven and used for the next cycle. The suspension was diluted with EtOAc and H2O. The organic layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10 mL) and dried with anhydrous Na2SO4, then subjected to reduced pressure to remove the solvent. The mixture of 1,4 and 1,5 disubstituted triazole products was further purified by column chromatography on silica gel (200 mesh) using ethyl acetate: hexane (30:70) as an eluent to afford the desired product, for example, 3a about 0.068 g. The products were confirmed by MASS, HRMS, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies [ESI]. 2.5 General method (B) for Ni catalyzed in-situ generated azide-alkyne cycloaddition (NiAAC) The mixture of alkynes 1 (0.5 mmol), benzyl/phenacyl bromide 2 (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (0.75 mmol), and 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH (0.05 g) were added to a 10 mL round bottom flask in 4 mL of H2O (solvent) at room temperature. The mixture was refluxed for 10 h at 80 °C in the open air. The remaining procedure is similar to what has been described in the general procedure A. 2.6 Characterization of the catalysts For brevity and to circumvent self-plagiarism, the experimental conditions pertaining to BET-SA, powder XRD, H2 - TPR, NH3 -TPD, SEM – EDX, 29Si SS-MAS NMR, XPS and H2-pulse chemisorption details are reported in electronic supplementary information (ESI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the catalysts The N2-physisorption analysis (at −196 °C) revealed that the rice husk-derived SiO2 showed a high surface area when compared to the NiO/SiO2-RH samples (Table 1 ). The surface area of the support is gradually decreased when NiO (5 to 15wt%) loaded on the SiO2-RH [40]. The decrease in specific surface areas of the NiO/SiO2-RH samples are explained due to pore blocking of nickel oxide particles in SiO2-RH. The active metal surface area of NiO/SiO2-RH catalysts was determined by H2-pulse chemisorption (Table 1). The 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst exhibited a relatively higher nickel metal surface area than the other loadings. The activity data over different NiO loaded SiO2-RH revealed a direct correlation between dispersion of NiO and the rate of triazole formation (Table 2 ). 3.2 Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out to understand the crystalline structure of nickel loaded SiO2-RH catalysts and the patterns are reported in Fig. 1 . All the XRD patterns showed a broad peak at 2θ = 22∘, which is a reflection of amorphous silica, [41] along with fcc-NiO phase with characteristic peaks of the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes corresponding to NiO (PDF# 04–0850) reflections at 2θ = 37.8°, 43.3°, 62.8°, 74.8 °, 79.5° respectively (Fig. 1A) [42]. The sharp peaks indicated that the crystallite size of NiO has increased with an increase in NiO loading. The XRD pattern of bulk NiO was exactly matched with the diffraction lines observed over nickel loaded on SiO2-RH samples (Fig. 1B). The crystal size of fresh calcined nickel samples is reported in Table 1. The used 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH sample exhibited more or less similar crystallite size (∼9.72 nm) and the bulk NiO showed 14.30 nm. The fresh and used forms of 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH samples showed similar patterns, emphasizing that there is no change in crystalline phase during the course of reaction and the stability of the catalyst under the reaction conditions applied (Fig. 1B: c, d). 3.3 H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis The reducibility and interaction of NiO with SiO2-RH is investigated by H2-TPR (Fig. 2 ) and their corresponding H2 uptake values are reported in Table 1. The TPR profiles showed broad and unresolved peaks, indicating two stage reduction of NiO particles, which are bulk NiO (large sized) and finely dispersed NiO species [43]. All the samples showed a low temperature reduction signal at 365 °C and a broad peak in the high temperature region of 450–500 °C. The low temperature peak at 365 °C is ascribed to the reduction of finely dispersed NiO and high temperature signal can be due to large sized clusters of NiO species on the SiO2-RH [44]. These results are in good correlation with the increased crystallite size of nickel at higher loadings observed from the XRD analysis (Table 1). With an increase in nickel loading, the H2 uptakes are also increased exemplifying the bulk property of the H2-TPR technique. 3.4 NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis The acidic properties of NiO-loaded SiO2-RH samples were analyzed by TPD of NH3 and the profiles are reported in Fig. 3 . The NH3-TPD profiles exhibited two broad peaks, one at a low Tmax≈180 °C and the other one at a high temperature of around 600 °C [45]. While measured the specific NH3 uptakes (normalized with the corresponding specific surface areas of the samples); it was observed that the 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH exhibited lower NH3 uptake (57 µmol/gcat) than the other nickel loadings (Table 1). 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis The XP spectrum of 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH fresh calcined and used samples are reported in Fig. 4 A. The Ni 2p spectra shows 2p 3/2 signal at 854.18 and 2p 1/2 at 872.4 eV which correspond to NiO species at the near surface region [46]. The corresponding satellite peaks observed at 861.9 and 879.2 eV were in good correlation with earlier reports [47]. The peaks at 861.9 and 879.2 eV are the satellite peaks of Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2. The difference between the two peaks of NiO is 17.3 eV further confirming the existence of NiO species on the surface [48]. The XP spectrum of the used catalyst (recovered after the reaction) showed similar spectral lines, emphasizing no change in the surface structure of the catalyst during the course of the reaction. The Si2p spectrum (Fig. 4B) shows a signal at 102.2 eV that is attributed to SiO2 at the near surface region [49]. However, the Si 2p spectrum line was slightly broadened in the recovered catalyst. The O1s peak observed at 531.5 eV is due to oxygen coordinated to surface nickel cations [50]. 3.6 29Si-SS MAS NMR analysis The 29Si-SS MAS NMR study provides information regarding the structural environment of silicon atoms in the SiO2 matrix. The 29Si-SS MAS NMR spectra of the NiO/F-SiO2 and NiO/SiO2-RH (fresh and used) samples are presented in Fig. 5 . The spectrum of fresh calcined 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH contains a strong shift at-111 and-108 ppm attributed to siloxane bonds of crystalline trydimite [Q4, Si(O)4] and silanol groups of -cristobalite [Q3, Si(Si-O)3(OH)] in the silica framework [51]. The shoulder peak in the chemical shift range of −102 to −106 ppm, which corresponds to silicon atoms in silane diol groups [Q2, (OH)2Si(Si-O)2], [52] where the superscript indicates the number of siloxane bonds. The 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH used catalyst and 10wt%NiO/F-SiO2 also exhibited (±2 ppm) the similar NMR pattern. The 10wt%NiO/F-SiO2 sample exhibited much larger line widths and shifted to downfield compared with the spectrum lines of the 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH fresh sample [53]. Based on the 29Si-SS MAS NMR results it can be summarized that a majority of Q4 environment is observed in the rice husk derived SiO2. 3.7 Catalytic activity measurements 3.7.1 Screening of reaction conditions We started NiAAC with 4-(trifluoromethyl) phenylacetylene (1a) (0.5 mmol) and 4-azidonitrobenzene (2a) (0.45 mmol) over bulk SiO2-RH, which yielded a maximum of 18% 3a (Table 2, entries 1 and 2), whereas bulk NiO yielded lower 3a yields (Table 2, entries 3 and 4). Upon dispersing the NiO on SiO2-RH the desired product yields were tremendously improved. The 5wt%NiO/SiO2-RH (≈0.05 g) catalyst, DMF as solvent at 60 °C for 10 h afforded very lower yields of 3a ≈ 30% and 4a ≈ 11% (Table 2, entry 5). An improvement in the 3a product yield is observed while DMF is replaced with water (Table 2, entry 6). The reason for the improved yield can be explained by the polar solvent that favored the formation of the desired compound due to its hydrophilic interactions. Because of its polar protic character and electrostatic interactions, water is an excellent solvent for 1,3-dipolar cycloadditions. Several previous reports also mentioned that triazole yields were particularly high in polar protic solvents. The comparative rate of triazole formation in water and organic solvents has not received the same level of attention. It has recently been demonstrated that increasing the mole fraction of water results in a significant increase in 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition rates [54]. In water, the polarity and hydrogen bonding of the transition state were increased [55]. Upon increasing the Ni loading, i.e.7.5wt%NiO/SiO2-RH, it showed a significant improvement in yield of about 72% of 3a along with 8% of 4a (Table 2, entry 7). To our delight, when the reaction was performed using 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH, the desired product (i.e., 3a) was found to be 93% yield (Table 2, entry 8). At higher nickel loading, i.e., 15wt%; it showed a more or less similar activity (Table 2, entry 9). For comparative analysis, 10wt%NiO supported on fumed SiO2 was tested under identical conditions, which showed inferior activity than on the NiO supported on rice husk derived SiO2 (Table 2, entry 10). The reaction was performed using varied amounts of catalyst (10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH) such as 0.025 g, and 0.075 g, and the corresponding results are reported in Table 2 (entry 11 and 12). At a catalyst loading of 0.025 g, we observed a lower rate of the product 3a with 2.35 µmol gcat −1s−1 (Table 2, entry 11). Upon increasing the catalyst amount to 0.075 g, the rate of the product 3a is found to be 1.56 µmol gcat −1s−1 (Table 2, entry 12), suggesting that 0.05 g of catalyst is enough to achieve a high rate of the 1,4-disubstituted triazoles. These experiments were performed in the absence of a base unless otherwise mentioned. It is noteworthy to mention that at higher nickel loadings (at and above 10wt%) selectivity towards 3a is 100%. Quite a contrast to this, both the 5 and 7.5wt% NiO/SiO2-RH demonstrated the ‘4a’ product of about 10%. Furthermore, to decrease the reaction time to 7 h, we used various bases such as TEA, DIPEA, Cs2CO3 and K2CO3, which showed lower yields when compared with a reaction time of 10 h (Table 2, entries 13–16). When H2O was replaced with other solvents such as ethanol, dioxane, THF and toluene, product yield was drastically decreased (Table 2, entries 17–20). The reaction was performed at ambient temperature under identical conditions; a lower yield of 16% 3a and 8% 4a was obtained (Table 2, entry 21). At a reaction temperature of 45 °C, about 62% of 3a and 5% of 4a were found. When the reaction was performed at different temperatures, 45 – 100 °C, a high rate of 3a at 60 °C and at high temperatures (>60 °C) formation of 4a was observed. However, at higher temperatures, the rate of the click reaction was higher, though the regioselective purity of the product was found to be low (Table 2, entries 22–24). Upon increasing the substrate concentration from 0.5 to 1.5 mmol, the product (3a) yield was gradually decreased to 64%, possibly due to the insufficient number of active NiO sites on the catalyst surface for triazole formation (Table 2, entries 25–28). The mixture of 1,4 and 1,5 disubstituted triazole products are separated by flash column chromatography using silica gel (200 mesh) with the required ratio of EtOAc: hexane (30: 70) solvents. However, we mentioned how to calculate the percent composition of each product in [ESI]. 3.7.2 Substrate scope Under the optimized conditions (Table 1, entry 8), the substrate scope was examined with various aryl alkynes (1a-1d) and organic azides (2a-2 g, 2i, 2j) and the results are summarized in Fig. 6 . It is interesting to note that various aromatic alkynes and azides bearing both the electron-donating and withdrawing groups underwent the azide-alkyne cycloaddition to give the corresponding 1,4-disubstituted triazoles in good to excellent yields (67–93%) with high regioselectivity. The aryl acetylenes bearing trifluoromethyl group (1a) gave the corresponding 1,4-disubstituted triazoles with yields of about 93, 91, 88, 85 and 87% (Fig. 6; 3a-3f). Interestingly the product formation was not observed with the 1-azido-2-nitrobenzene (2c), which was explained due to the ortho and steric effect of the electron-withdrawing group (-NO2). The aryl alkynes with alkyl (4-ethyl1b, 4‑tert-butyl1c) gave good yields of 1,4-disubstituted triazoles with regioselectivity (Fig. 6; 3g-3q) and traces of compounds 4 m, 4n and 4p. However, the yield of the product was slightly decreased in the presence of a bulky group (tert‑butyl) on the phenyl ring (1c). This could be possible due to the steric congestion between the substrate and the surface-active sites (NiO). In addition, the reaction of carbohydrate azides (2,3,4,6-tetra-O-acetyl-β-d-glucose azide (2i) and 2,3,4,6-tetra-O-acetyl-β-d-galactose azide (2j)) with various aromatic alkynes could afford up to 90% yields (Fig. 6; 3q-3t). Various aliphatic alkynes such as 1-nitro-4-(prop‑2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene (1e) and 1-hexyne (1f) reacted efficiently with various azides to give the corresponding 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole (Fig. 7 ; 3aa-3ai) in good yields with regioselectivity. But unsurprisingly, 1-hexyne (1e) gave lower yields compared to other alkynes. This can be explained by the fact that alkyne contain an electron-donating aliphatic chain. The other alkynes with tricyclic groups such as carbazole, phenothiazine and phenoxazines gave excellent yields and regioselectivity. Using 1-azido-3-nitrobenzene with tricyclic terminal alkynes 3-(N-carbazolyl)propyne, 10-(prop‑2-yn-1-yl)−10H-phenothiazine and 10-(prop‑2-yn-1-yl)−10H-phenoxazine gave the product with excellent yields of 92, 85 and 87% respectively (Fig. 7; 3aj, 3an and 3ar), while with the 1-azido-4-bromobenzene produced 86, 83, 85% yields (Fig. 7; 3ak, 3ao and 3as). In contrast, the electron-rich group substituted 1-azido-4-methoxybenzene produced good yields of about 81, 74 and 78% respectively (Fig. 7; 3al, 3ap and 3at). Finally, the tricyclic aliphatic alkynes react with benzyl azide products were formed with good yields of about ∼87, 81 and 84% respectively (Fig. 7; 3am, 3aq and 3au). The aforementioned all tricyclic contained alkynes showed good regioselectivity, and the electron-withdrawing group bearing various alkynes and organic azides gave excellent yields and regioselectivity with NiAAC. 3.7.3 One-pot synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles from in-situ generated azides We also examined the 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst to synthesize the 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles with good yields in one-pot from various alkynes and in-situ generated azides (Fig. 8 ). Initially, the phenylacetylene 1d was reacted efficiently with benzyl bromide 2k giving the 3v an 80% yield (Fig. 8). We further extended the triazole products from one-pot synthesis by reacting highly active organic halide, such as phenacyl bromide 2l with phenylacetylene 1d to afford the corresponding 3 w about of 83% yield (Fig. 8). The 1d further reacted with a strong electron-donating group baring phenacyl bromide 2 m to obtain the 3x in a 76% yield (Fig. 8). In the final attempt, the reaction between n‑butyl propiolate 1j and 2k produced 3y with an 81% yield. (Fig. 8). 3.7.4 Mechanism Based on the aforementioned investigations and literature reports [17,18,56], a plausible mechanism for the Ni-catalyzed 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole synthesis has been proposed in (Scheme 1). The terminal alkyne first coordinates with surface nickel, forming a nickel-complex species, and then reacts with azide to form transition state A. The CN bond formation between alkyne and azide generates intermediate B. Subsequently, the intermediate B undergoes reductive elimination, leading to the formation of a target product and regenerating the active species on the catalyst surface. The Sharpless-Meldal version (CuAAC catalyst) explains that the primary step proceeds through the initial intermediate (copper acetylide) by oxidative incorporation of Cu(I) into the CH bond of a terminal alkyne. The next step involves combining the copper acetylide with the terminal nitrogen of azide to form a 5-membered cyclic organ copper intermediate and it is further hydrolyzed with water to yield 1,4-triazole. But the NiO/SiO2-RH catalyzed "click" reaction followed a different mechanistic path than the Sharpless-Meldal version. To better understand the mechanism of the NiAAC reaction, we used the deuterated alkyne substrate. We propose that the first step is the formation of a nickel-π complex. To demonstrate the formation of nickel-π complex species, we performed the reaction between deuterated alkyne 1k and azide 2d using the general procedure A for NiAAC to form a deuterium 1,4-triazole 3 u. We observed almost 100% retention of deuterium in product 3 u (Scheme 2), which was confirmed by 1H NMR [S3, S22, S68]. Ni could play a key role in bringing the reactants together through Ni-π complexation and coordination with terminal nitrogen of azide. If the reaction goes through Ni acetylide formation, the deuterium present on terminal acetylene carbon changes to hydrogen. This result indicates that Ni does not insert into the CH of terminal alkyne in the first step to form Ni acetylide. Thus, the reaction could proceed through acetylene π-complexation on the Ni surface to form π-complex followed by azide cycloaddition to form 1,4-triazole. Plausible orientations of the Ni-π complex are shown in Scheme 2. The sterically less hindered Ni-π complex (a) is more favored for the high regioselectivity of 1,4-triazole during the course of cycloaddition. 3.7.5 Structural properties of the 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst To understand the relationship between surface NiO species and the triazole formation activity, we carried out various characterization techniques. Based on the catalytic activity data and the physicochemical characteristics, it can be summarized that a 10wt%NiO supported on SiO2-RH demonstrated excellent yields of the triazole product formation. The formation of the desired triazole product is dependent on nickel dispersion on the catalyst surface. The H2-pulse chemisorption data clearly showed that a higher nickel dispersion over 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst indicates that surface ionic NiO is the active species for the triazole formation. The 10wt%Ni/SiO2-RH catalyst showed a high percentage of Ni dispersion on SiO2-RH (4.3%) with a Ni metal surface area of (26.9 m2g−1) that demonstrated high yield and selectivity of triazole product compared to other nickel loadings (Table 1). It was found that crystallite size increased gradually up to 10wt%NiO loading and 15%NiO/SiO2-RH showed a bigger crystallite size of 13.1 nm (Fig. 1A) and H2-uptakes are increased upon an increase in nickel loading on support (Fig. 2). It indicates that 10wt%NiO exhibited a small crystal size with high dispersion on the surface. It is very interesting to note that a lower surface acidity is observed over 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH compared to other loadings. For comparison, we performed the reaction with a F-SiO2 supported 10wt%NiO catalyst, which demonstrated lower activity than the NiO/SiO2-RH. The rate of triazole product formation was higher over the 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst that possessed lower acidity and higher nickel dispersion (Table 1 and Table 2). The XP spectra of fresh and used 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst revealed that Ni species are in Ni2+ state and there was no change in the oxidation state of nickel in the catalyst recovered after the reaction. It is interesting to mention here that the local environment around the -Si- is not changed even after the reaction, which was confirmed by the 29Si-SS MAS NMR results. 3.7.6 Recyclability studies The recyclability studies on the 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst were performed by using 4-(trifluoromethyl) phenylacetylene (1a) and 1-azido-4-nitrobenzene (2a) as model substrates in H2O at 60 °C for 10 h, that showed a stable activity for four successive cycles with consistent yields (Fig. 9 ). The ICP-OES analysis of fresh and used samples of 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH showed 9.81 and 9.74% of nickel, respectively showing its stability (Table S1). This was further supplemented by the XPS analysis, which confirmed that there was no change in the surface structure of the used 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst (Fig. 5). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have established a method for the regioselective synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles constructed from organic azides and alkynes by using 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH as an efficient and reusable catalyst. The demonstrated catalytic system could tolerate a large variety of functional groups, including electron-rich and electron-poor substrates, as well as heterocyclic azides and alkynes. Finally, the following conclusions are drawn based on the results obtained using a cheaper heterogeneous 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst with renewable biomass such as rice husk derived support i.e. SiO2: • Under mild reaction conditions achieved high regioselectivity with good to excellent yields, • Reaction performed in aqueous media, one of the green protocols, • Under ligand and base-free conditions, • Easy separation of catalyst for reuse, • High product rate, • Detailed mechanism using deuterated alkyne as an example, • A broad substrate scope (with carbohydrate click chemistry), produced more than 90% of the desired product under the experimental conditions adopted. coredata.dc:description: SiO2 derived from rice husk (SiO2-RH) has been used as a support for NiO catalyst for azide-alkyne cycloaddition in aqueous media at 60 °C. The 10wt%NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst was found to be an efficient and reusable catalyst for the regioselective synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles with broad substrate scope that included carbohydrate triazoles and one-pot synthesis of triazoles. The reaction mechanism followed through a nickel π-complex on the surface of the NiO/SiO2-RH catalyst. The catalyst was recycled up to four times that showed consistent activity and selectivity. The structure-activity correlation and mechanistic studies were established by BET-SA, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, SEM-EDX, XPS, XRD, 29Si SS MAS NMR and H2-pulse chemisorption studies and a plausible reaction mechanism has been proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Renewable SiO2 as support for NiO catalyst for regioselective synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles from azide-alkyne cycloaddition in aqueous media
